name: Kepler-256
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-256 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-256 is a star with 1.694 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.3 times its radius. It is located 3448.64 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-256 is known to have 4 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-256 b

Kepler-256 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.03 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 1.62 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-256.

The mass of Kepler-256 b is 2.94 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-256 b is 1.59 that of Earth. At 2.94 Earth masses, Kepler-256 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-256 c

Kepler-256 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.04 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 3.39 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-256.

The mass of Kepler-256 c is 6.05 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-256 c is 2.15 that of Earth. At 6.05 Earth masses, Kepler-256 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-256 d was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.06 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 5.84 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-256.

The mass of Kepler-256 d is 8.49 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-256 d is 2.48 that of Earth. At 8.49 Earth masses, Kepler-256 d is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-256 e was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.10 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 10.68 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-256.

The mass of Kepler-256 e is 7.51 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-256 e is 2.35 that of Earth. At 7.51 Earth masses, Kepler-256 e is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-256, which contains 4 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
